lesson_title: The Vector of Direction: Particle へ (e)
lesson_summary: This lesson introduces the particle へ (e), which functions as a directional vector. While 'ni' marks a specific point, 'he' (pronounced 'e') indicates the direction or orientation towards a destination.

grammar_explanation.concept: The particle へ (written as 'he' but pronounced 'e') indicates direction. In a logical framework, if 'ni' is a specific coordinate (a point), 'he' is a vector (an arrow pointing towards a target). It is often used with verbs of motion or to describe spatial orientation.
variations: Often paired with other particles like 'wa' (へは) for emphasis or 'yori' (へより) to indicate 'from the direction of'.
common_confusions: vs に (ni): 'ni' is the destination or static location (At/To). 'he' is the direction (Towards).

teaching_sequence.content: In previous lessons, we looked at particles that define static roles: the subject (wa), the object (wo), and the location (ni). Now, we move from 'points' to 'vectors.' In Classical Japanese, when a poet wants to emphasize the movement or the orientation towards a distant place—like the open sea or a loved one's side—they use the particle へ (e). Think of it as the 'Towards' operator in your spatial logic.

display.text_with_furigana: <ruby>たまも<rt>aquatic plants</rt></ruby><ruby>かる<rt>harvest</rt></ruby><ruby>おき<rt>offshore</rt></ruby><ruby>へ<rt>towards</rt></ruby>は<ruby>こかし<rt>long for</rt></ruby><ruby>しきたへの<rt>pillow-epithet</rt></ruby><ruby>まくら<rt>pillow</rt></ruby>の<ruby>へ<rt>direction</rt></ruby>の<ruby>ひと<rt>person</rt></ruby><ruby>わすれ<rt>forget</rt></ruby><ruby>かねつ<rt>cannot</rt></ruby>も
display.romaji: tamamo karu oki e wa kokashi shi kitae no makura no e no hito wasure kanetsu mo
display.translation: I yearn towards the offshore where seaweed is harvested; I cannot forget the person who was at the side of my pillow.

teaching_sequence.content: Notice how へ (e) appears twice in this poem. First, in 'oki e' (towards the offshore), it acts as a directional particle. Second, in 'makura no e', it functions almost like a noun meaning 'the side' or 'the direction of'. This highlights the origin of the particle: it comes from a word meaning 'side' or 'area.' When you see へ, visualize an arrow pointing from the subject toward the noun.

display.text_with_furigana: <ruby>わか<rt>young</rt></ruby><ruby>には<rt>garden</rt></ruby>の<ruby>ふゆき<rt>winter trees</rt></ruby>の<ruby>う<rt>top</rt></ruby><ruby>へ<rt>direction</rt></ruby>に<ruby>ふる<rt>falling</rt></ruby><ruby>ゆき<rt>snow</rt></ruby>を<ruby>うめ<rt>plum</rt></ruby>の<ruby>はな<rt>flower</rt></ruby>かと<ruby>うちみつる<rt>look at</rt></ruby>かも
display.romaji: waka niwa no fuyuki no ue ni furu yuki wo ume no hana ka to uchimitsuru kamo
display.translation: Looking at the snow falling upon the winter trees in the young garden, I wonder if they are plum blossoms.

vocabulary.meaning: to look at / to fill the gaze

teaching_sequence.content: In the phrase 'ue ni' (うへに), we see the evolution of へ. 'U' (top) + 'he' (direction) + 'ni' (at) = 'At the top direction' (Above). While 'ni' tells us the snow is *at* a location, the 'he' inside the word 'ue' provides the spatial orientation (upwards). In Classical Japanese, many spatial nouns are built this way.

display.text_with_furigana: <ruby>おき<rt>offshore</rt></ruby><ruby>へ<rt>towards</rt></ruby><ruby>より<rt>from</rt></ruby><ruby>みちくる<rt>rising</rt></ruby><ruby>しほ<rt>tide</rt></ruby>の<ruby>いやまし<rt>increasingly</rt></ruby>に<ruby>あか<rt>bilge</rt></ruby>も<ruby>ふき<rt>wipe</rt></ruby><ruby>み<rt>see</rt></ruby><ruby>かみ<rt>upper</rt></ruby><ruby>ふね<rt>ship</rt></ruby>かもかれ
display.romaji: oki e yori michikuru shio no iyamashi ni aka mo fukimi kami fune ka mo kare
display.translation: From the direction of the offshore, the tide comes rising increasingly; look at the bilge water being wiped from that ship.

teaching_sequence.question: In Poem 3, the phrase is 'oki e yori' (おきへより). Based on the particles, what is the logical flow of the tide?
teaching_sequence.answer: The tide is coming 'from' (yori) the 'direction of' (e) the 'offshore' (oki).
teaching_sequence.hint: Break it down: Oki (Offshore) + e (Towards) + yori (From).

reference_card.one_liner: A directional particle indicating 'towards' or 'in the direction of' a noun.

forward_references.note: We saw 'yori' in Poem 3. It marks the starting point or source, often paired with 'e' to define a path. We will cover it in the next lesson.
This is a verb in its 'Rentaikei' (attributive) form, which we will analyze in Unit 3.
